abstracts.cdata!:
This first phase of the Sana'a
            Basin Water Management Project will assist the Government in
            containing the depletion of groundwater in the Sana'a
            Basin aquifer, a timing which will allow for the conversion
            of the Basin's economy into less water-intensive
            activities, while favorable socioeconomic conditions will be
            encouraged through community participation. The first
            component seeks to achieve water savings, and conservation
            in agriculture, by increasing irrigation uses through
            physical interventions in upgrading piped delivery systems,
            converting open channels to piped delivery systems, and
            introducing pressurized irrigation, promoting community
            participation. The second component will accelerate
            groundwater recharge, through small conventional dams,
            sub-surface dams, and other structures. Given the flaws of
            the Water Law, the third component will help develop a
            regulatory framework, to subsequently apply regulatory
            procedures for water rights management, and, the National
            Water Resources Authority will assume the responsibility for
            basin-wide water resources investigation, regulation, and
            monitoring. Moreover, a basin hydro-geological and water
            resources investigation, and monitoring will aim at
            analyzing project impacts on dam, and wadi structures
            regarding aquifer recharge, and groundwater levels,
            including as well, surveys, laboratory testing, and
            satellite imagery/aerial photography to quantify impacts on
            crops and irrigated areas. The fourth, fifth and sixth
            components, will promote public awareness campaigns,
            environmental management, and mitigation plans, and, support
            project management activities, respectively.
